 These include non-chemical pest management practices that treat pest problems rather than preventing their occurrence, or biochemical pesticides that control pests by non-toxic mechanisms (i.e., naturally occurring substance). This category excludes biological pest management and cover cropping.
Do you grow or encourage the cultivation of perennial crops?
Do you employ organic or other low-input farming practices (that have not yet been considered) or encourage the adoption of such practices?
Do you improve pollination through the temporary introduction of domesticated pollinators (local or exotic) or encourage the introduction of pollinating species?
Do you foster farming systems that reduce the use of harmful inputs (other than those already mentioned) or encourage the adoption of such farming systems?

Do you encourage selective combinations or integrations at the farm level to optimise ecological synergies? 
 This concerns synergies between and among plants, livestock, aquatic animals, trees, soils, water and other components on farms that optimise ecological functions and ecosystem service delivery.

Have you adopted or do you encourage integrated pest management practices related to habitat manipulation, for instance, through improved landscape planning, or when using habitat management for biological pest control?

Have you adopted, or do you contribute to more widespread adoption of landscape planning that bolsters ecosystem services beneficial to agriculture?
 This includes consideration and coordination of activities which include land use, land cover or other components at the landscape level that optimise ecosystem services that benefits agricultural production. It also includes habitat conservation around agricultural lands, or landscape-scale management interventions.

Have you adopted or do you contribute to greater adoption of practices that mitigate climate change by sequestering soil carbon or reducing GHG emissions? 
 This category includes only types of systems where the whole agroecosystem is fundamentally redesigned.
Do you take steps to ensure greater systemic resilience of agroecosystems to extreme weather events or other disturbances?

Do you take steps to ensure greater systemic resilience and adaptive capacity to changing environmental conditions due to climate change (e.g., salinity, average temperatures, new emerging pests and diseases), through undertaking research or developing an adapted system to future conditions?
Do you take steps to ensure greater livelihood resilience to stress and shocks (e.g., economic, weather shocks) by offering diversified income, production and access to the market?

Do you involve farmers in the creation of knowledge and/or sharing of knowledge? This includes promoting exchanges between farmers, guiding participatory research approaches OR supporting farmer-researcher networks.
Do you promote participatory and multi-stakeholder approaches to knowledge generation by integrating farmers and other actors' views?
Do you provide or promote greater formal and non-formal education about food production and sustainability related food topics?
Do you engage in or promote capacity-building for diverse stakeholders within and beyond your organization?

Do you take actions to support healthy, diversified and culturally appropriate food traditions and diets?
 This concerns food systems that provide healthy, diversified, seasonally and culturally appropriate diets, while supporting and protecting cultural identity and values of local communities.
Do you empower people to make more informed decisions about the quality and type of food they hunt, fish, gather, grow and eat?
Do you develop, inform, or influence policies and other approaches that empower and support groups that have been typically marginalized?

Do you support adequate access to food by all people by developing and informing policies, methods and approaches that ensure the right for people to feed themselves in dignity, ensuring that sufficient food is available, that people have the means to access it, and that it adequately meets the individual's dietary needs?
Do you develop and inform policies and approaches that allow communities to decide the way food is produced, traded and consumed?
Do you actively support workers' rights to free association, collective bargaining and worker-formed associations?
Do you work on increasing organisational capacities of farmers' communities and other local food system actors?
Do you take action to support fair, dignified and inclusive livelihoods for all actors engaged in food systems?
Does your enterprise hire rural youth, or does it support the creation of decent jobs for youth in the food and agriculture sector by actively participating in policymaking?

Do you structurally support local suppliers and local hiring practices? 
 Please note that 'local' is defined as being part of the same community.
Are at least 75% of the full-time employees across the organisation paid Living Wage (or an equivalent - see this link)?

Do you structurally provide high-quality jobs or professional development opportunities for individuals with chronic barriers to employment?
 Depending on the local context, this can refer to people with physical or mental disabilities, social groups facing discrimination, social exclusion or stigma.

Do you actively promote a diverse workforce through specific hiring practices, structurally encouraging different facets of talent?
 Depending on the local context, diversity in emplotment can imply differences of gender, ethnicity, sexual orientation, age, disabilities, immigration background and/or low-income status.
Do you take steps to ensure fair pricing and fair payments to suppliers, sufficient to cover cost of production, including living wages or equivalent for any workers throughout the value chain?

Do you help re-establish the connection between producers and consumers, or provide business support to do so?
 This includes the provision of support related to the development of local food systems, short value chains and webs, and developing trading relationships with local growers.
Do you actively encourage the creation of value in your region by connecting local producers with other activities that add value, such as processing, packaging, and post-harvesting?
Do you endeavor to grow demand for seasonal and regional products?
Do you contribute to the development of policies or public knowledge related to the links between agroecology and global changes, such as climate change?
Do you develop, inform, or encourage national-level legislation, policies and programmes that reward or otherwise incentivise agroecological approaches?
Do you proactively promote access to land for a range of stakeholders, particularly those with structural barriers to access (e.g., factors related to capital or market access)?
Do you inform public policy or enforce company policies that establish closer connections between producers and consumers (short distribution networks)?
Do you develop, inform, or encourage participatory decision-making that aim for a sustainable and equitable food system?
Does your enterprise have policies or put in place incentives aimed at ensuring the equitable governance and traditional rights over natural resources?
Do you engage in multi-stakeholder, pre-competitive partnerships that help to mobilize and share knowledge, expertise, technology and financial resources, to support greater uptake of agroecology?

Net farm income-crop (USD farm−1): Income from crop. Additive indicator.
Net farm income-livestock (USD farm−1): Income from livestock. Proxy for the degree of integration between farm enterprises (additive).
Agricultural income (USD head−1): Estimated income per head. Proxy for the capacity of farmers to invest in sustainable intensification (additive).
Income from off-farm (%): Indicates alternative sources of livelihood to support investment on the farm (additive).

Access to inputs for crop production (binary): Farmers' access to inputs for crop production is recorded as binary (0, 1) from farmers' interview. Indicates financial and physical capital necessary to achieve more productive use of land (additive).
Access to bank credit (binary): Data collected quantitatively from farmers' interview. Access indicates opportunities to invest in sustainable intensification (additive).
Access to veterinary services (binary): Recorded as binary (0, 1) from farmers' interview. Access shows the level of risk a farm is facing (additive).
Access to training (binary): Recorded as binary (0, 1) from farmers' interview. Indicates farmers' exposure to theoretical and practical aspects of improved farm technologies (additive).
Farm experience: Number of years the farm household head is farming. Represents farmers' knowledge (additive).
Education of household head: Level of education, illiterate (0), primary (1), secondary (2), higher education (3), etc. Shows the level of farmers' awareness (additive).

Livelihood strategies: Number of livelihood strategies farms are practicing were recorded from farm interview. Proxy for diversity of income sources and farm capacity to invest in agriculture (additive).
UREA applied (kg ha−1): Quantity of UREA applied (kg ha−1) to crop land. Shows the degree of N mining or over accumulation in the farm (additive).
DAP applied (kg ha−1): Quantity of DAP applied (kg ha−1) to crop land. Shows the degree of N and P mining or over accumulation in the farm (additive).
Water use (m3 ha−1): Absolute volume of water used per cultivated hectare. Represents the amount of water drawn from hydrological systems (subtractive).

Application of FYM (kg ha−1 on dry matter basis): Quantity of manure applied recorded from farm interview. Shows the degree of nutrient recycling and soil nutrient replenishing, and also crop livestock interaction (additive).
Depth of groundwater (m): Estimate of the average depth of farm tube well. Proxy for groundwater depletion (subtractive).
Irrigation method: Methods a farm is practicing, flood (1), furrow (2), sprinkler (3), drip (4). Proxy for water use efficiency (additive).
Crop diversity: Ratio of the number of crops to total farm cultivated areas. Shows on-farm genetic resources conservation (additive).
